title: German Social Democrat leader to resign after breast cancer diagnosis
text:
German Social Democrat leader Manuela Schwesig. | Adam Berry/Getty Images German Social Democrat leader to resign after breast cancer diagnosis Manuela Schwesig is one of three lawmakers currently co-leading the SPD.

BERLIN — One of Germany's three Social Democrats leaders, Manuela Schwesig, announced Tuesday she had been diagnosed with breast cancer and will step down from her duties at national level.

"The good news is that this cancer is curable," Schwesig announced Tuesday, DPA reported. "However, it requires medical treatment. This will mean that I will not be able to attend public appointments every day in the coming months."

Schwesig informed colleagues about her state of health during a Cabinet meeting of the regional government in Schwerin, Mecklenburg-Pomerania, a federal state in Germany's north. Schwesig has been the state premier since 2017 as well as the local party leader.

"After intensive discussions with my treating physicians, I am very confident that I will be able to fully recover again," the 45-year-old said. "That is why I have decided to continue to hold the office of state premier and party leader here in the region [of Mecklenburg-Pomerania]." However, Schwesig added, that it was "also clear that in the coming months I will have to concentrate my energies on Mecklenburg-Pomerania, my health and my family. Therefore I will resign from office at national level."

Earlier in June, Germany's Social Democrats picked Schwesig together with her party colleagues Malu Dreyer and Thorsten Schäfer-Gümbel to act as a trio of interim leaders, following former leader Andrea Nahles' decision to step down and leave politics. It is not yet clear whether the party will pick a successor to Schwesig or continue with a dual leadership until its party congress in early December, where the Social Democrats will vote on a new future leadership.

The SPD, the junior coalition partner to Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives, suffered heavy losses at May's European Parliament election and barely clung to power in a regional election in Bremen. The party is polling at historic lows, achieving just 13.5 percent in recent polls.
